name.value: Suffragettes In and Out of Prison

item.description:
Rules from game itself:

Directions for playing the Great Suffragette game:
"HOW TO GET OUT OF GAOL"

The suffragettes (i.e. the card disks) are first placed on the inner circle. (Holloway Goal).

The players alternately throw the dice, and at each throw the player moves his Suffragette round the spiral course, the same number of spaces as the number thrown.

Should a number be thrown which would bring a suffragette on to a space marked with either of the undermentioned words, she must be move as directed, viz. :-

"OPEN DOOR" The suffragette must be placed on the adjoining space in the next circle further away from the goal.

"POLICEMAN" or "WALL" The suffragette must be placed on the adjoining space in the next circle nearer to the goal.

"WARDRESS" The suffragette must be put back in Holloway Gaol and recommence her journey.

The player whose Suffragette first reaches the end of the spiral course wins the game. As a puzzle, the problem is to see what is the fewest number of throws you can get your Suffratette out of goal, following the same rules as for the game.

This is a small, pocket-sized trivia game. It contains 50 cards with 3 questions each, most of them with multiple choice options. The backside of each card contains the answers and offers additional information. Most of the cards also show small illustrations.

The ultimate knowledge-check! Test your skills on the subject of logic puzzles! Confusing and challenging puzzles to think about.

SOlve the puzzle first and get the card.
Player with the most cards at the end of the game is the winner.

Orsay is a quiet rural town 22 km from Paris, which dawns infested with grotesque creatures, undead, they multiply rapidly and roam the city looking for new victims ... The year is 1899, you are a survivor in this hell on earth, you should survive or become a WALKER!

Walkers is a board game for 2-6 players created by Julio Trois, which is about a zombie apocalypse at the turn of the twentieth century, where you must survive with a small group of people, using equipment found in a city taken by undead creatures.

Players can play with the heroes or the zombies, each turn move the board, collecting equipment, fighting zombies, seeking to perform the missions of the game. Walkers is a fast, easy, strategic, collaborative, where players view the action from the start!

item.description:
The game is a contest of occupation featuring two players around a grid board representing the streets of Edwardian London. One player plays 21 green markers as the radical suffragettes, the other player plays 21 dark blue markers as the police constables. The objective of the suffragettes is to break through police lines and enter the House of Commons, while at the same time preventing the police from entering Albert Hall. The objective of the police is to disrupt the meeting of the suffragettes by entering Albert Hall, while at the same time preventing them from entering the House of Commons.

"Arrested" suffragettes are confined to the "prison" section of the board, whereas "disabled" constables are confined to the "hospital" section. The game is won by the first player who introduces six markers into the opponent's base.

Source: Suffragetto, https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Suffragetto&oldid=833508008 (last visited June 16, 2018).

item.description: From the box. A wild and frantic speed game that everyone plays at once. The game is described and a great party and family fun game based on the fast style of play. It is a race to get rid of all cards by playing onto a center stack. Teams or individuals play provides hours of exciting family & party fun. 3 decks of 168 cards numbered 1-12 in 3 colors. Game can be played in teams or individually. All 3 decks are shuffled individually then passed, 5 cards dealt up and 12 cards dealt down. Then panic begins. As each card face up is played, it is replaced by one of the 12 down card. This continues until all 17 cards are played and the first player out of cards yells panic. But remember it takes a #1 card to start a stack. Then the cards are separated by team color and scored as per the instructions. The first team to reach 200 is the winner.

From the rules
"A domino type game, consisting of 49 card depicting seven species of birds, in which the Males (M) and Females (F) differ in their plumage. The game is played by identifying and matching the correct males and females. There is also one card for each species depicting the Young (Y)."

The game is played in a traditional domino manner except you are matching male and female pairs, and you are able to add a young below a 'paired' male and female (in which case you are able to take an extra turn). The winner is the first player to get rid of all the cards in his hand, or if the pack becomes exhausted and no one can 'go' the player with the least cards wins.

The cards have realistic artwork depicting the birds in a style similar to a bird reference book.

There is also another game variant included in the rules, called 'Bridges' which is for two players, and involves players creating columns of matching pairs of the same species or families of the same species, and bridges between the two players columns. Points are awarded for creating 12 card columns, and for creating bridges between columns. Games continue until one player has scored 30 points.

Objective: be the first to pass finish line (field 50)
learn more about flying a glider
- moving by turns/simple 'Roll and Move' game -

meeples are moved according the die roll; 
ending on a marked space follow instructions..

remarks:
published between 1939 - 45 (see logo)

Roll 5 dices and try to achieve the highest score. The rolls are entered in a 5x5 sheet, and the score is the points on the dice. Later in the game the rolls have to match the numbers already in the protcol. After 10 turns (5 horisontal lines and 5 vertical lines)
the highest score wins

A Checkers variant played with red/white reversible pieces, five to each player, on a 6 x 7 grid of red, white, and blue squares. The rules on the back of the box include three variants of the game.

Each player starts on either narrow side of the board; the objective is to capture all the opponent's pieces to win. Movement of the pieces is dictated by the color of the square which each piece is on. Pieces are captured by landing on them, turning them over, and placing them on the capturing player's side of the board. The three variants have slightly different rules to increase difficulty of winning.

Checkers with 4 players on a 14 x 14 grid, with the 9 squares of each corner cut out. 12 pieces to a player; game starts with pieces laid out in usual checkers fashion but on four sides of board. Rules for 2 player and partners variants are included.

The game's box boasts: "First NEW CHECKER GAME in over 3000 years"

Promotional board game as an award for "Happy Digits" premium customers of T-D1.

Communicative game with many notions about telecommunications and mobile communications and also on general topics. The terms are either paraphrased, pantomime presented or drawn. In the category of "Creativity" creative brainstorms are exchanged.

6 game figures, 4 x 33 cards, one die, 1 set of instructions

The first print run was limited to 5,000 copies.

Promotional board game for children of the Nuremberg insurance policyholders. Illustrations and game pieces are in the design of "Biene Maja".

The game features two games in one: â€¨ A classic "Ludo", which is named "Biene Majas Wiesenrennen" ("Bee Maja meadow race") here, and a running game about the company's junior breakdown cover, where the children have to safeguard themselves against hazards â€¨ and at the end of the game to have as much money as possible.

Includes: double-sided game plan at 360 x 360mm, â€¨ 16 pieces (4 pieces per style), 1 dice, 33 green event cards, 33 red hazard maps, 85 insurance policies, 150 play money bills

The print run was limited to 5,000 copies.

Two to six players must illustrate a lot of baking-specific terms through pantomime, drawing or describing them. The other players have to guess the words. It is not quite as easy to define Donauwelle, mime yeast, or draw rye bread, so this can become quite adventurous and funny.

Game Contents: 1 game board, which illustrates the genesis of a bread from the wheat fields to the bakery, 99 action cards, 6 pawns, 1 game instructions

This is a small, pocket-sized trivia game. It contains 50 cards with 3 questions each, most of them with multiple choice options. The backside of each card contains the answers and offers additional information. Most of the cards also show small illustrations.

The title translates to "English grammatic".

This is a tower-building game using plastic building blocks in eight colors.

The blocks are retrieved from a box with 6 x 6 compartments. Only a few compartments are available at any time decided by dice rolling. As a part of game setup the building blocks are put in the box and the box is shaken upside down and then right side up to randomly divide the blocks in the compartments.

From a deck of "building orders" a row of four available orders are drawn and two rows above it forms a future market.

Each player gets a set of six action cards numbered 1,2,2,3,3,4, four special cards and a base plate in his color to build the tower on.

The game is played in six rounds. Each round starts with that each player secretly chooses one of his six action cards. Everyone reveals which card they chose and each player gets as many actions as the number on the card. The cards are discarded after each round and cannot be used again.

The players take turns performing one action at a time and does one of the following:

- Take blocks from one allowed department. 
- Choose a building order card and build (but you have to have the blocks first). When a card is chosen the cards above are moved down and the lower is made available. Add a card from the deck to the empty space on the top row. 
- Discard all available build order cards, move down the cards from the upper rows and refill the top row.
- Reroll the dice that decides which compartments are avaialble. 
- Pass (do nothing).

At the end of each round the dice are rerolled to descide which compartments are available next round. Discard all available build order cards, move down the cards from the upper rows and refill the top row.

Some of the build orders are special and are not built until the end of the game where they allow you to add blocks to your tower depending on how your current tower looks like (color patterns).

Some build orders uses blocks from your opponents supply, or even tower. Some changes the order of blocks in the tower or adds blocks in the middle of a tower. Some cards are used to manipulate actions and order of actions.

Highest tower wins!

The title translates to "German for foreigner - vocabulary".

The night before June 6th, 1944, more than ten thousand Allied paratroopers were dropped into enemy territory to prepare the Normandy landings – but the troop-carrying planes were blasted by German anti-aircraft fire, scattering their airborne troops everywhere but where they were supposed to be.

You are one of these paratroopers. And as luck turns out, the winds have blown you directly where you are needed the most! As you were descending, you discovered a terrible sight: the Germans have installed two 24.0 cm Guns in a hidden bunker. Those cannons are set to fire at the beaches of Normandy. You alone can stop them from killing the Allied troops! All you need is some explosives...

In Airborne In Your Pocket, players explore their surroundings by placing Location tiles and resolving Event cards every turn. They must find the Ammo Dump to obtain some explosives and enter the bunker to sabotage its guns. Of course, there are German soldiers everywhere, so players will have to hide or fight their way through.

AIYP can be as simple (Basic Game) or as involved (Scenarios & Campaigns) as the player wishes. The Advanced Game and Scenarios allow you to play as American, British, Canadian and French soldiers. The game comes in four different sets, and each set has enough components for one player. To add more players, add more sets (up to four can play).

Reimplements:


 Airborne in my Pocket

DungeonRaid is a new fantasy deck-building game designed to capture the charm and atmosphere of the console RPGs of days long gone.

The game begins with a small card draft to determine starting equipment. Then, in a classic Deck-building fashion, players purchase weapons, armor, and spells in turn and use them to fight monsters and bosses; all of which come into the supply randomly. Used equipment cycles back through the deck as it needs to be repaired and the player's goal is to collect the most wealth from the Dungeon while at the same time trying not to be the first to get killed.

"Staged" levels of difficulty increase the challenge at regular intervals and also introduce improved Treasure to the supply. This aspect also makes the game highly expandable, and gives it immense replay value.

(Tentatively) Recommended for 2-5 players, but solitaire play will be an option.

[This game is still in development, and development is currently on hold. Release date is yet unknown.]

The board is a web with holes in the intersections. The pieces are pegs that have numbers printed on them. Each peg can move the number of spaces printed on it. Some pieces can land on other pieces and remove them from the game. Each player moves their pieces along the web aiming to get their pieces to the opposing player's start space. the piece is then put into the player's safe zone. The winner of the game is the player that gets the most pieces into the safe zone.

The boardgame based on the popular Dutch television show "Wat vindt Nederland?" in which two teams compete against each other, trying to find out what the general Dutch opinion is. Teams will get a statement - mostly based on recent events - and have to try and guess what the opinion of the Dutch public is on the statement. Whichever team is closer, wins the round.

Just like the RTL4 show this game is about opinions and how well you think you know them. The game uses a large variety of recent issues on which popular opinion has been polled. Your task is to find out which is the general consensus among the Dutch audience and score points by doing so.

In Alliances, you will play a superpower nation seeking world domination along with its ally. The game is mainly based on trick-taking mechanisms, with each trick representing a local struggle to control a country in the world. The world is composed of a vast number of countries, each one represented by a tile on the table. Each country also has its own defensive attributes: a certain military strength, economic strength and political strength which need to be overcome. In order to win, your alliance has to dominate the world by gaining control over the most countries.

Alliances includes three different games in one box:


 For 2 players, a confrontational trick taking game.
 For 3 players, a game in which each player in turn plays a superpower empire while the other two players fight him off as rebels.
 For 4 players, a game in which you and your ally will team up to fight your rival alliance to control the world!

name.value: Pixel Patch: The Real Life RPG

item.description:
Ever want your playing cards to be used for something more than a poker hand? Ever want to turn those hearts into healing items and those clubs into cash? We’ll, now you can.

Pixel Patch: The Real Life RPG is a 2-6 player card game that turn a standard deck of 52 cards into a a fun 8-bit RPG-influenced battle system. Players will try to work their way past their opponent’s defense through the cards they draft and grow more powerful through the games they play.

Every round, you will choose cards to decide whether to attack, defend, heal or gain influence for special abilities. You and your opponent will then decide whether to perform your action in an aggressive or defensive fashion and then draw a varying number of cards to determine your success.

This entire game can be played with just a deck of cards and a pad of paper if necessary, but player aids and guide books are also provided in the downloadable PDF.

The game ends when a player’s health reaches 0. At this point, experience points are handed out, which allow you to level up, boosting your original stats from your entrance exam and making your card drafts more powerful. All these stats are recorded on the printable booklets that come with the game.

This game is a great head to head challenge as you work to figure out what your opponent will do next and of course is immensely repayable as you work to unlock and master 11 unique classes.

Players can also boost their stats by purchasing RPG Patches from our website (listed in the links section); each one of these patches gives a different permanent stat boost to your character, without breaking the game.

item.description: Players spin the dial and pump the flower once for each ladybug that appears in the spinner wheel until the balloon ladybug flies away.The balloon gets larger with each pump and if it flies away on your turn you win.

Which TV series has more consequences: Dallas, the Black Forest clinic or Star Trek? And whose rates were better?

The categories are so specific that even players who are very much interested in the given topic (like Cult TVseries in this case), probably will not know the correct answers. Instead, every player has to do the best guess.

MechaWar is the first title from the One Pound Wargames imprint of Precinct Omega Publishing. The game gives complete rules for building your forces of mighty mech walkers and pitting them in intense tactical combat against your opponent.


 Use simple resource allocation to build and customize your force of mechs in minutes.
 Play on any flat surface with a few pieces of terrain and any collection of mecha miniatures.
 Skirmish-style action with alternating activation, each mech operating independently.
 Intuitive combat uses dice to generate both range and accuracy for shooting as well as to resist and repair damage.
 Manage your actions to pursue your objective or react dynamically to your opponent's manoeuvres.
 Works for scales from 6mm to 15mm.
 Includes advanced rules to customize your mechs as engineer, minelayer, commander or assault mechs.
 Includes three starting scenarios.


This game eventually evolved into "Horizon Wars" published by Osprey

item.description:
62 exciting issues from politics, history, geography and science.

In player's turn his left neighbor reads aloud a question.
If he answer corretly he receives one point and must answer another question. Otherwise, the next player has a turn. The winner is whoever has accumulated the most points at the end.

name.value: Grandma's Game of Knots and Whys of Science

item.description:
Question and answer game where each player is trying to answer the most questions correctly. Similar to McLoughlin's Gandmama series of games.

This game had 199 question cards, an answer book, and a set of instructions in the box.

In the 1860's the McLoughlin Brothers introduced a successful series of educational card games under the name "Grandmama's XXX Game." The first series included card games on Arithmetic, Geography, Riddles. and Useful Knowledge.

One player was designated the "preceptor" and the other players were "scholars." The preceptor would ask questions and go around the players until someone got the question right. Most right answers wins.

"Grandmama's Old Testament Questions & Answers" card game had 100 question cards, an instruction sheet, and an answer booklet which were packaged in a paper covered cardboard box.

In Suspend, you want to be the first player to get rid of your share of the 24 notched, rubber-tipped wire pieces that come with the game. How do you get rid of them? Throw them away? Hide them under a cushion? No – you must hang them from a shared tabletop stand, using only one hand to place the piece on an unoccupied space. If anything touches the table after you place your piece, you must remove and reposition it; if anything falls off, you have to keep those pieces and try to hang them again on future turns. The first player to suspend all of her pieces wins!

item.description:
The game is basically a children's race game with no decisions. In this regard it is like Chutes and Ladders. The theme is riding your pony from start to the finish line.

There is a twist on the Chutes and Ladders type game. There are two card decks from which a player may get a move card on his turn. However the player must flip a supplied "coin" to see if he gets a card from the Johnny stack or the pony stack. having each player flip a coin would thus make "individual" luck come into play as opposed to both players just playing against a randomized deck.

The game had 4 riders and horses. It cam in a cardboard box that was somewhat like a pizza box.

Basically this is a children's game which is a combination of Bingo and Old Maid. Instead of doing a blind draw, each player spins a wheel on his move to determine which picture to cover up on his 'bingo" card. If he spins the Old Maid, then he takes possession of the Old Maid token. When the first player completes his card, then whoever is holding the old Maid marker loses.

Basically a Bingo game with a "spin." The six 4x4 playing boards are printed onto a large roll-up mat. Rather than a blind draw, on his turn each player spins a wheel to find the picture he can cover up. First person to complete a line of 4 wins. on his board wins.

name.value: Chitty Chitty Bang Bang Movie Quiz

item.description:
This was a licensed game with a tie to the movie of the same name. It had Dick Van Dyke on the box top. It is essentially a movie trivia game.

Sheets of questions are supplied, and the player gives an answer then completes the circuit to show the correct answer for that question by turning on a light.

Each player has a top to spin on the board which has holes. When a player's top lands in a hole he scores points. The player gets four spins per turn.

Two ways to win. First on total points. the first player to reach 400 points wins.

Second way to win is score points in each turn for one of the four weapons ( anti-aircraft gun - 25 pts, gun truck - 10 pts, plane - 50 pts, and tank - 75 pts) to capture. First player to capture all four weapons wins.

Rules state - "Our Defenders Game can be player by two, three, and four players. Each players selects a different cutup figure [ie 1 of 4] and separates same. The first player spins spinner. If it points to figure he selected, he takes one cutup part of figure. Next player spins and plays in same manner. If spinner points to a figure other than the one selected, player loses his turn. The game is continued in this manner until one player has completed his figure. The First player completing his figure is the winner."

A Medieval miniature wargame for armies consisting of 10-15 units. Game play is driven by an orders chart, each player choosing a set number of actions for the turn (such as Shoot, Battle, Charge, or Move).

The rules are short, simple and give quick games. Unit types are abstracted, so all knights perform in a similar way, all missile troops are similar, and so on.

The game may be played with 6, 10, 15, or 28mm models or with counters.

Game description from the publisher:

In front of you lies the untouched soil of Germany. No track is cutting through its plains, no station is telling of the great industrial progress – but you are about to change that.

In Express 01, you can invest in the construction and upgrading of railway lines and build stations for different companies. When you upgrade such a station, you may reassign it to another company. Your main focus is the acquisition of shares, and as soon as shares are issued, trains can run on behalf of the companies. This way money will be distributed to the shareholders and you get new capital. So keep an eye on the other players to earn money or obstruct their opportunities.

The game ends after the round in which a certain number of Base Cards is upgraded or a certain number of decks are used up. The player who managed to gain the most capital wins.

Moderate in-game text - needs crib sheet or paste ups
Extensive use of text - massive conversion needed to be playable

item.description:
108 game cards with 500 questions and 500 answers about Euro 2008 soccer cup.
The question is asked and the quickest player with correct answer gets a point. Who collect 25 points first wins the game.

Contents:

 108 playing cards, 
 notepad and pencil

Nebraska's Best Trivia was developed to bring hours of fun while teaching interesting facts about the great State of Nebraska. Nebraska's Best Trivia is designed for any number of players; individual play or 2 to 4 teams of 2 to 4 players on each team.

The object of the game is to complete a score card by answering trivia questions from five different categories and be the first to cross the finish line with a completed score card. But watch out! You must avoid setbacks and potential disasters brought on by your opponents as they try to complete their score cards and cross the finish line before you.

Translated from Dutch:
"You know Scrooge McDuck loves his money. On the board you can see him running in anger around the tree. He is mad because the Beagle boys turned on the windmill and now his money is blown away. He tries to catch the money. He now gives a reward to the player who stops the windmill. Donald, Huey, Dewey and Louie would like to profit this chance. Therefor they travel to the windmill. Winner is the player who reaches the windmill first."

The game is a roll and move game with some extra's. At the start of the game players receive two planks. While travelling to the windmill players must cross the water and use these planks. When they roll a 3 or a 6 they can pick up a plank from the board.

In Bonkan, players are explorers traveling through ruins and looking for anything they can find. Players will discover both artifacts and traps, then must decide to go on exploring or escape.

Every round, each player decides to continue or exit the expedition. If you choose to continue, you draw a card. Items found have weights, from heavy treasures to lighter artifacts (which are useful against traps). Each player that continues has to contend with this accumulating weight. Disasters and traps also come up in play, and a player can get stuck in the cave if they get too heavy or get stuck in a trap. Players who don't make it out score nothing for their treasures.

At the end of the game round, the player with the most points wins.

New York Quiz is a game for anyone who has ever visited New York City, or dreams of doing so! With 170 tricky questions and fascinating facts about the Big Apple, everyone will find something to tickle their brain cells with. It's the perfect way to warm up to a coming New York trip, or remember it once you are back home.

There are 2 question in each card and answers on backside.
Player who answers correctly first gets the card as a point.

Each Anno Domini set consists of 336 cards, with a description of a historical event on one side of the card, and the year in which it happened on the other.
Each player receives nine of these cards, and may only look at the descriptions. Each player in turn puts a card on the table, trying to put them in chronological order. A player may, instead of adding a card, claim that the order in which the cards were put is incorrect. In this case all cards are turned over and the correct years revealed.
If the order was correct then the doubting player receives two cards and skips a turn. If the order was incorrect then the previous player, who accepted the order as correct, receives three cards. The first player that gets rid of all the cards wins.
Bluffing is as least as important as knowledge in this game. Most events are rather obscure and are hard to date.

Part of the Anno Domini series.

link.value: Cities: Hanover or Hannover (Lower Saxony, Germany)

item.description: Dexterity game where the players are trying to build a tower out of wooden beams. The "twist" on the "normal" game is that the tower is built on a rotating turntable. Whoever knocks any part of the tower down loses.

name.value: Bitter Heights: The Battle of Mitla Pass – October 29-31, 1956

item.description:
Bitter Heights: The Battle of Mitla Pass: October 29-31, 1956, is a low-complexity game on the battle for Mitla Pass during the 1956 Arab-Israeli War. The Israelis were to take and hold the Pass to prevent Egyptian forces from reinforcing their counterparts to the east, as well as establish a credible force that could threaten the Suez Canal. This would provide the pretext for Great Britain and France to intervene and take the crucial waterway back from Egyptian control.

The battle would come to represent the confused and tragic aspects of this war. The Israelis underestimated the strength of their opposition, the indecisive actions of their British and French allies upon which this operation depended, and the diplomatic victory Nasser and the Arab Allies would realize despite the military defeats they sustained. General Sharon’s controversial decision, to attack and take control of the pass in disobedience of direct orders, led to high losses in a fight that did nothing to further the Israeli cause.

As the Israeli player you will have to keep your losses low, while keeping hold of the roadway through the pass, as the Egyptian player you want the Israeli's to pay a high price.

Activation takes place by the use of a deck of cards, similar to the Pocket Battle Games by ATO. This creates the chaos of war that makes play unpredictable and interactive.

Game Scale:
Game Turn: 3 hours
Area: 1 inch equals 2 miles / 3.2 kilometers
Units: Battalion to Army

Game Inventory:
One 11x17" full color map
One dual-side printed un-mounted countersheet (90 1/2" counters)(mounted counters are optional)
One 4-page rulebook
One Player Aid Chart

Player Provided: One 6-sided die

Solitaire Playability: Medium
Complexity Level: Low
Players: 2 or more
Playing Time: 2 to 3 hours

Victorious advance!

A new game from our Air Force by H. Kallenberger from the collection "Scholz's artistic games".

This game is adapted from real live and provides a fairly accurate picture of the use of air power. In it the combat units (bombers) are used to advance far into the enemy rear. These are heavy machines, suitable for carry large bomb loads over long distances.

The goal is to destroy the HQ of the opponent by hitting it with a bomber(only a bomber). Play also ends if the one of the player's HQ's has no place to move or if the player has lost all his bombers.

Sea Chess is a board game, like Chess, or Checkers. Chess, however, is a game that interprets Medieval land warfare while Sea Chess interprets a modern Naval Battle. Every Sea Chess game piece represents a warship. Both players get 24 game pieces representing 3 battleships, 4 cruisers, 8 destroyers and 9 escorts. Each type of "ship" moves freely about the board with its own characteristic motion, speed and direction. The "ships" are engaged in dynamic moving action until sunk and you can watch all of the action.

In Sea Chess there is a gradual "sinking" instead of "jumping" or "taking" pieces. A game piece moves into range and "fires". A roll of the dice determines a successful hit. Each type of "ship" has its own characteristic striking force and range. Pegs are placed in the pieces to record successful hits. When the holes are full, the piece has been "sunk". Since a peg marks each successful hit, you can keep track of how much damage you are doing to your opponent's ships.

READY REFERENCE CARDS included with the game give you a neat summary to keep by your side as you play so you do not have to keep looking into the rule book for speed, direction, striking force, etc.

RANGE GAUGES are provided to help you determine what ships are in range and which are not. Soon you will be able to tell just by looking which ships are in range.

You develop the strategy! You make the plans! You decide whether to make the first attack or prepare a devastating counter-attack!

From the game page on The Game Crafter

For too long the Meeples have lived under the boot of the mighty Regime. You have been pushed around and mistreated while the Regime grows rich off your toil. No longer! The day has come to rise up and take control of your fate. The day has come for Uprising!

Uprising is a semi-cooperative game for 2-4 players who take the role of rebel groups rising up against the vicious Regime. Will you be able to work together to overthrow your oppressors, or will you turn on the others to try to become number one?

Summary of Game Play

The board is a grid, where each cell ("sector") can be controlled by a player, by the regime, or by nobody. Each turn, players draw tiles indicating where they can take actions, such as attacking or reinforcing. After all the players have taken their turns, the regime takes 3 automated actions in random sectors. Each battle can be fought with military power, or with popularity.

The game ends when any player (or the regime) reaches a target score, based on popularity and sectors controlled. At that point, the force with the highest score wins, and if the regime is highest, all the players lose. In the standard rules, players can directly attack each other or temporarily align with the regime. There is a fully-cooperative variant, where players face a stronger regime.

An LPS bonus mini-game, Terrible Swift Swordfish is a solitaire simulation of the Royal Navy's bold and devastating attack on the ships of the Regia Marina in the port of Taranto during the night of November 11-12, 1940.

In two waves, the player send his Swordfish carrier-based biplanes laden with either torpedos or bombs to attack Italian ships or bomb port facilities respectively. Damage inflicted is determined by chit-pull (or dice rolling in the case of flak).

As additional Swordfish enter the map on their pre-designated bombing runs, Italian flak and anti-torpedo defenses grow more coordinated and deadly.

The player attempts to maximize his Victory Points by sinking ships and bombing facilities, all while trying to avoid the loss of his Swordfish Biplanes.

Immortal is a strategy game of warring mythologies, combining area control and card battle play. The war of the gods has begun... Born from the dreams and nightmares of mankind, mythic beings are gathering forces to crush their enemies. They have put their fate in the hands of mere mortals like yourself, granting you the power to lead them to victory. Capture your opponents’ forces, turn their powers against them, and forge your own legend!

In Immortal, ancient gods, heroes, and monsters battle for control over mythic realms. 2 to 4 players assume command of powerful pantheons summoned from world mythologies - Master Set One features the Norse, Greek, Japanese, Celtic, Egyptian, and Native American pantheons. Each pantheon of character cards offers unique abilities and strategies to be mastered. Battles take place on a battlefield created from modular board tiles, representing the nexus of mythical realms. The goal of the game is to control the most cards on the battlefield by capturing your opponents’ cards and defending your own.

During the game, players take turns placing their character cards on the spaces of the board. Each card has a distinct combination of battle strengths, represented by numbers on its four edges. When a card is placed on a space adjacent to the north, south, east, or west edge of an opponent’s card, an attack begins and the strengths on the cards’ touching edges are compared. If the attacker’s strength is greater, then the defending card is successfully captured, giving the attacking player more control over the battlefield. Special abilities can influence the results of an attack, and set the board up for future combos by strengthening allies, weakening enemies, and bending the normal rules of the game.

After the first battle, players upgrade their pantheon decks with more powerful cards, and expand the battlefield with additional modular boards. Victory goes to the player who controls the most cards at the end of two battles. Game variants allow players to form teams, change the rules of engagement, or play faster matches. Once players have mastered the basic strategies of the game, they can mix and match characters from different pantheons to build their own custom decks. As Immortal evolves, more pantheons will be added from the myths and legends of distinct cultures. These expansions will introduce new boards and cards, and new abilities and playing styles to the game.

item.description:
A building game where players are acquiring all of the elements the need to build a three-story tower. Players use cards to buy equipment from the stock -- H-beams and joints create substructures, and V-beams are used to build to the next story. The goal of the game is to be the first player to build a three-story building that consists of three substructures separated by V-beams, and a roof.

Game play consists of turns where players either buy materials, or use purchased materials to build building elements. Unbuilt raw materials are vulnerable to card-play from other players that may require them to give over unused materials, or may cause a player to return all unused materials to the supply. Additionally, some special action cards prevent a player from building until the player resolves a strike, either through the payment of money, or the play of a contract card.

name.value: Mage Tower: A Tower Defense Card Game

item.description:
Mage Tower is a tower defense card game for 1-4 players that combines the frenzy of tower defense games with the replayability and customization of fantasy card games. Each game you make a unique deck from over 170 different spells and abilities. You and opponents pick from a selection of cards to build your deck. Focus on card combos, synergy, balanced energy costs, and watch out for your opponent's strategy!

During the game there are two decks: the Monster Deck and your customized Player Deck. Each turn monsters come out of the monster deck to attack you, and you use the cards from your Player Deck to deal damage to them, draw cards, mess with opponents, and more. There are also some subtle deck building elements with "Prize Cards" you can buy during the game to add to your deck. The first players to lose all their life from the monsters lose.

name.value: The People vs. O.J. Simpson Trivia Game

item.description:
Object of the Game: As an investigator, your job is leave your color start position and make your way, by answering questions, to the six locations on the map, and return to your position before your opponents do.

Possibly a prototype of a game that was to be sold and money raised was to be used for OJ Simpson's defense. The game may have been banned and/or rejected and never mass produced.

name.value: Pointless Wacky Untested Game I Made Up One Afternoon

item.description:
INTRODUCTION:
Want to play a game that is literally untested, unproven, and that was made up one afternoon for a game contest? You've come to the right place then!

This is a game that makes absolutely no sense, but you may end up having fun anyway, just for spite.

So, roll up your sleeves and let's get started!

DESCRIPTION:
This game is primarily a party or icebreaker game where people take turns to try to complete challenges.

GAME OBJECTIVE:
Be the player with the lowest score at the end of the game

GAMEPLAY:
Players each receive tokens (of 4 varying colors), and then each player takes turns completing challenge cards. If a player is successful, they will generally reduce the number of tokens that they have (which are worth points). If a player fails a challenge, they will gain tokens. Each player is trying to gain the lowest score possible. Challenges are each very unique, and can be physical, logical, luck, or knowledge-based.

GAME ELEMENTS:

Light-hearted gameplay
 Players can learn more about fellow players in a fun way
 Token point system keeps everyone involved

Similar electroni game than Electro but instead of questions-answers there are pictures. The two plug are connected to each end of the battery and when the plugs are placed on the two points that are connected (i.e. the pair of pictures belonging together) the lamp will shine to indicate this.

Electronic battery operated matching game has 10 different pages to play. When you match one picture on one side of the page to a picture on the other side of the page with the electric wands, a red light lights up at the bottom of the game to show that you are correct.

Player with the most correct answers is the winner.

Exercises Snake Game is a gambling game. Players would put up stakes (money) to play and then divide the stakes according to the outcome of the game.

The game notes that it is "to be played with a tee-totum, or with dice."

The game has a snakes with number 1 near head and number 54 near the tail. The snake is laid out in s curves along the vertical direction. he sections of the snake are in different colors to show Charles Magnus' printing ability. The page is also decorated with men exercising for the same purpose. They have no absolutely no function in the game.

The special positions on the snake are colored red and are have special instructions.

2 - Gives the player two throws more
 9 - 1 more throw
 20 - Go back to No. 4
 27 - Advance to 32.
 33 - 1 more throw
 40 - Gives the player one-half of all the stakes
 46 - Stop for the next turn
 52 - The player has lost and must cease to play
 52+ - Those who throw over 52 divide the balance
 of the stakes


More to "More"

This particular image found on the web was a sheet of paper which had the game on one side and a handbill advertising Charles Magnus' wares on the other. The handbill side indicates that this is one of 12 such games printed on a paper sheet and available for purchase.

The thriving colonies of Zel'var are the destination for many adventurous souls who choose to leave the solar system and good old planet Earth seeking a new life and good fortune – but not all find what they are looking for. Many become disillusioned, discontent even, and turn to pirating the prosperous trade routes between the five planets, much to the regret of the colonies' leaders, who have great need of the trade income in order to advance technologies and create jobs for the newly-arrived colonists.

Colonies is a game of resource management in the far reaches of space in which the players compete to dominate in trade, politics and technological development. Each player controls the administration of a planet with access to a unique resource. In order to win you need to collect the most colonial credits by trading resources, upgrading your technologies, keeping your trade lanes free of pirates, and perhaps pushing the council's decisions in the right direction.

At the begining of each turn, players receive an income of their own resource. The council meets each turn to vote on how to handle an occurring event. The outcome can reward those willing to put in an effort or punish those who are not. Players may do well to form alliances in order to sway the vote in a favourable direction.

The resource income and the colonists that arrive each turn – sometimes in large numbers, sometimes in small – are used to make advances in five areas: Community, Military, Commerce, Influence and Industry. Following the council's vote, players take turns to either upgrade these areas or activate one of them to grant asylum to pirates in exchange for resources or hunt them for bounty, sell resources for Credits, make trade agreements more beneficial, or produce additional resources. When everyone has had three such actions, the players receive and pay resources according to the trade agreements, and any colonists that players have failed to employ turn to piracy, preventing players from getting income from their trade agreements next turn unless preemptive action is taken.

Colonies lasts ten turns, with players earning victory points (VPs) from colonial Credits and technology advances. In the end, the player with the most VPs wins.

item.description:
A children's game published in the French comic/magazine Francs Jeux.

The game has two boards. The first is a short Monopoly-style track. The aim is to land on squares featuring the six items that you need before you can try to fly to the moon. Movement is dictated by a die roll (you must supply your own die). The spaces you must land on to get these six things are:
T = Launching pad
F = Rocket
A = Apollo Capsule
L = Lunar landing module
J = Moon Buggy
E = Crew

When you have acquired these, you move to the second board. This is a traditional one track game (á la the Game of Geese). If you land on special spaces, you must obey the instructions. The first to get to the moon, wins.

Abstract two player game with a soccer theme. The player that scores more goals than the other after an agreed time wins.

Each player has a team consisting of 11 figures. The playing field consists of 83 spaces with connections between them. On each space there can only be one figure or the ball.

On each turn a player can kick the ball in a straight line if he has a player next to the ball and move one of his 11 figures one space. If a player cannot kick the ball he can move two figures one space each (or one figure twice).

There are some more rules like fouls, passing or kicking the ball over an opposing figure.

Objective: Be the first moving up to field 108
 - moving by turn -
throw the die and move according rolled number; ending on a marked space follow instructions glued on cover inside.

A dice and card game for two to four players. In your turn, you roll the dice and if you roll a total on one of your cards, you can discard it. If a player is dealt an "X-IT" card, it may be used as a wild card, i.e., 1 to 6. First to discard all their cards, wins. X-IT cards held by the losers, count as 6 points, other cards as at face value.

Trivia game in the architecture domain.

Basically Trivial Pursuit but with questions about architecture, architects, and building technique. There is a similar board type with the looks of a round technical drawing. The pawns are a famous building each. There several type of questions; famous buildings, architects, quotes and images.

The main goal is to reach the center of the board by answering trivial questions of cards that relate to the place of the pawn.

It was the age of gods and goddess. Zeus (King of the Gods), Poseidon (Lord of the Seas), and Hades (God of the Underworld) had agreed to separate the sky, the ocean, and the underworld. Athena, the Goddess of Wisdom, would take over the rest of the earth. But the Norse gods were displeased by the decision. They called warriors and disciples to take the world from the Greek gods. The gods atop Mt. Olympus also called their warriors to defend them. During this war of the gods, a mass of warriors died, and their souls were sealed in a jar.

And now they are waiting for you to release them.

In the deck-building game Kanzume Goddess, you will be one of the Gods of mythology. Each God in the game has its own special powers which players can use to their benefit. Players will purchase cards from the center of the table to add to their decks. They will use these cards to purchase more cards and to do battle with the other players. These cards can be used to damage other players, to gain more cards, to draw more cards from your deck, and to protect yourself from damage. The last player with energy left is the last God standing and the winner of the game.

Kanzume Goddess can be played as an individual match with 2-6 players or as a team match if you play with 4 or 6 players.

link.value: Kanzume Goddess: Thor, God of Thunder
Kamigami Battles: Battle of the Nine Realms

item.description:
The aim of TOTEM is for your chief to build their totem pole before the other chiefs do, but it's not as easy as it sounds!

Players first decide how high totem poles need to be to win, between one and four totems, with higher poles meaning longer games. Cards in TOTEM come in three colours, representing the spirit power associated with them - red = power of destruction, yellow = power of protection, green = power of creation. Players are dealt at random a card representing their chief, and a spirit card (which is not looked at), which can be used as a risky last resort to destroy other player's totems, but can backfire and destroy yours (if the spirit card doesn't match the colour of the chief using it).

Players then take turns to turn over and collect totem part cards. To build a totem, players need to collect three cards, a wood, tools and paint card, in the same colour as their chief. Once they do this they discard those cards and choose a totem in their colour to add to their pole. There are several totem designs for each colour, so players can customize the way their totem pole looks.

Some cards in the totem parts deck are Magic Items - if a player picks one of these up and it is in their chief's colour, they can use it to do various things, from destroying other players' hands of cards (the Tomahawk), to preventing other players using magic items (the Teepee), or allowing them to look at other player's cards and swap any they want to (Pipe of Peace).

Once a player has created the set number of totems, they need to finish off by creating a Totem Topper (collect a wood, tools and paint card in each of the three colours in any order), and then they win! But play can continue to determine other placings.

Components:
Totem Parts (42 cards - wood, tools, paint, plus 6 Magic Items)
Totems (24 cards - 8 destruction, 8 protection, 8 creation, all double sided)
Chiefs (6 cards - 2 destruction, 2 protection, 2 creation)
Spirits (6 cards - 2 destruction, 2 protection, 2 creation)
Totem Toppers (3 cards, double sided)

Think Trunk is the perfect group and party game. Its unique game play allows for everyone to be involved on every turn.

There are 5 different categories on each card: Think It, Number It, Act It, Prefer It, and Wing It. All 5 categories encompass and expand on current games on the market but are adapted for multi-player input without teams.

The object of the game is to be the first player to get to the end and a single round takes 20-30 minutes.

Roll the Master Die to determine the "Point", then its off to the races as everybody rolls their 3 dice at once to score first! Roll High, Low, Odds, Evens, 3 of a Kind, or a Straight to win.

Roll the Master Die to determine what everyone is rolling for: odds, evens, three low, three high, low straight, or high straight. Players all roll at the same time and each player may "hold out" die as they roll the correct number. For example if you are going for "odds" and you roll a 1, you can place it aside and keep rolling to get the 3 and the 5. First player to get the correct roll, moves his/her marker along the score track. First to the finish, wins.
